repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Highway Sector Investment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Highway Sector
            Investment Program Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as sustainable, Bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The Country Assistance
            Strategy and the project objectives have been consistent.
            The project design also closely reflected the
            government's priorities as set out in their Road Sector
            Expenditure Program for 1996-2000. The Bank also helped to
            underscore the need to halt negotiated contracts, bring the
            major cause of the arrears problem to a close. Key lessons
            learned are as follows: The study undertaken to monitor the
            poverty impact of road rehabilitated and maintained under
            the project established direct correlation between improved
            road condition and access to higher order social facilities.
            The study also found other benefits accruing to people
            living along the rehabilitated roads. The project attests to
            the importance of program concept, which recognizes that
            road networks are interdependent, and thus improvements and
            extensions to the network must be planned within the context
            of the whole. The arrears to contractors in the sector shows
            clearly the need for comprehensive road sector management
            and transparent reporting. The government needs to institute
            a procurement policy to promote transparency. Development
            partners need to have better coordination to avoid
            duplication of technical assistance provision.

5077226.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Highway Sector Investment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Efficient cost effective road transport
            is fundamental to achieving the primary objective of the
            government of Ghana and the Bank of reducing poverty through
            increased growth, largely in the agricultural sector. The
            Highway Sector Investment Program Project will support this
            by: 1) reducing vehicle operating costs through maintenance,
            rehabilitation and reconstruction of roads; and 2) ensuring
            that improvements are sustained by developing and
            implementing cost recovery policies, building and utilizing
            indigenous capacity in the public and private sectors, and
            improving financial management and control. The main
            components of the project are: 1) maintenance,
            rehabilitation and reconstruction of the road network; 2)
            institutional strengthening and capacity building, which
            consist of strengthening the institutional capacity of the
            Ministry of Roads and Highways, the Ghana Highway Authority,
            the Department of Feeder Roads, the Department of Urban
            Roads, the National Development Planning Commission, and the
            domestic construction industry through appropriate
            institutional reforms, technical assistance, training and
            logistical support; and 3) policy reform including the
            following issues: cost recovery, private sector financing,
            increased environmental sensitivity, axle load control and
            road safety.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Highway Sector Credit Project : the
            environmental impact assessment study

abstracts.cdata!:
Environmental impact assessment (EIA)
            observations of the project road sections indicate that
            impacts will be fairly benign and limited to the local area
            where the road works will be carried out.  Severe
            environmental impacts necessitating resettlement of
            communities, or causing damage to fragile ecosystems will
            not occur to a significant extent as a result of the
            project.  Direct negative impacts will be limited to soil
            erosion which may be due to improper designs or embandments
            or side drains; scouring of the landscape due to opening of
            borrow pits; destruction of vegetation due to clearing
            right-of-way and a lack of adequate provisions for
            revegetation; dust, fumes, noise, and vibrations during road
            work; increased sediment loads in streams and rivers where
            road crossings occur; and safety hazards created by
            increased traffic flows and speed.  Secondary impacts from
            reconstruction will also occur.  Prominent among them is the
            possibilty of induced development along more accessible road
            corridors and opening up areas to natural resources to
            exploitation.  Positive impacts from road improvement
            activities occur and indeed provide the rationale for this
            project.  Examples include increase in value of agricultural
            products due to improved access to markets, enhanced
            roadside commerce and increased in social mobility.
